content: The "Veterans Appeals Improvement and Modernization Act of 2009" allows new evidence to be submitted directly to the Board for cases with pending appeals, bypassing the regional office unless requested by the claimant. This change will be effective 90 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Modification of jurisdiction and finality of decisions of the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. Modification of section 7252 of title 38, United States Code, grants the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims the power to affirm, modify, reverse, remand, or vacate decisions of the Board of Veterans' Appeals. These amendments apply to decisions made after the enactment of this Act. The Commission will study judicial review of veterans' benefits. The Veterans Judicial Review Commission is established to evaluate and improve the appellate review processes of veterans' and survivors' benefits determinations. It will make recommendations to enhance accuracy, fairness, transparency, and timeliness, including the possibility of allowing class action cases in the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. The Commission will consist of 13 members appointed by various officials. The Veterans Judicial Review Commission consists of 13 members appointed by different officials, including the Speaker of the House, President of the Senate, minority leaders, and the President. Members must be specially qualified for their roles. The Veterans Judicial Review Commission consists of 13 members appointed by various officials based on their expertise in areas such as veterans' benefits, judicial review, and constitutional law. Members can be current or retired judges, legal or academic professionals, or representatives of veterans service organizations, legal service organizations, or other affected entities. Each member serves for the life of the Commission. The Veterans Judicial Review Commission members serve for life, vacancies are filled as per original appointment, meetings are called by Chairperson or majority, majority constitutes a quorum, members serve without pay but receive travel expenses, and the Commission has a director. The Commission shall have a director appointed by the Chairperson, who may appoint additional staff as needed. The director and staff shall be appointed according to civil service laws and paid based on General Schedule pay rates. The Chairperson can also hire experts and consultants as required. The Commission, under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, may request personnel from federal agencies on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and administer oaths to witnesses. Members or agents authorized by the Commission can also take actions as needed. The Commission, authorized by this section, can take actions as needed. It can obtain official data from US departments or agencies, use the US mails, and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission, authorized by this section, can obtain official data from US departments or agencies and request administrative support services necessary for its responsibilities. The Commission is required to submit an interim report by July 1, 2010, and a final report by December 31, 2010, including specific recommendations and solutions proposed. The Commission will provide relevant background, statistical information, and other appropriate details for recommendations and solutions. The Commission will terminate two years after submitting the final report.
